Essay

sourceDesc.p: Born digitally, prepared by David C. Hanson.

div.head: Editing and Bibliography of the Early Ruskin Manuscripts
div.p: A map of how webpages are organized in the archive is provided in Plan of the Archive, and the planned contents of the archive are surveyed in Overview of the Manuscripts. Justification of the archive's organization and contents is offered in Editorial and Encoding Rationale and Methodology. Historical grounding for this justification is attempted in History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Manuscripts.

The present essay suggests pathways into the archive respecting the following topics:
Ruskin's First Editors and the Emergence of His Literary Personae
The Role of Ruskin's Early Works in the Emerging Bibliography and Collected Editing of Ruskin as a Canonical Modern Author
Ruskin's Autobiographical Uses of His Early Works and the Conception of Literary and Artistic Precocity
The Study of Ruskin's Early Works in Twentieth and Twenty-First Century Biography and Criticism

div.head: Ruskin's First Editors and the Emergence of His Literary Personae
Public Editing and Bibliography of the Early Manuscripts and Published Early Writing in the Fin de Siècle
div.p: (b) In the 1880s, Ruskin proposed to print selected early poetry and prose as a “supplement” to his autobiography, Praeterita. This link to the early writing was ultimately realized only in part, and not by Ruskin, but by his secretary, W. G. Collingwood, and his publisher, George Allen. Collingwood edited the Poems (1891), and he intended to edit the early prose also, but this complementary edition of the prose was never carried forward. Instead, Allen produced a series of editions of early prose work titles: . . . . For his original “supplement,” Ruskin presumably intended a more modest compilation, and one motivated in part, like the autobiography itself, as a testimonial to his parents, symbolically repairing one of his decades-old emotional rifts with his father—his snubbing of the older men's project celebrating the “poetic” aspect of his writing, which was precisely what Ruskin was striving, in the 1850s, to displace with a more critical approach in The Stones of Venice (1850, 1853).

The Poems (1891), however, should not be understood solely a belated realization of Ruskin's autobiographical project; the edition was driven also by motivations and underlying assumptions derived from broader cultural contexts of the 1890s. Collingwood reflects this context in the metaphors that open his introduction: “There is always a peculiar interest in watching development, in witnessing growth. When we have seen a plant burst the soil, . . . we love every leaf and petal of it: it is our own; and worth more to us than all the cut bouquets of a flower-show. And in the same way we delight in the early history of nations,--in the early biography of great men. As we follow their first steps, . . . they become our own by sympathy: and when they reach the day of victory and coronation, we seem, like the loyal adherents of a conqueror, to share the triumph; and, like intimate confidants, to understand the full significance of the achievement” (Ruskin, Poems [8o, 1891], 1:xix; Ruskin, Poems [4o, 1891], 1:???). In the odd mix of metaphors joining sympathy and ownership, Collingwood reflects attitudes that were fueling the Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries, a phenomenon that both stoked and responded to the market for acquiring first editions of works by modern authors. Especially valued were editions of authors' early works, preferably original first editions, but also facsimilie editions or fine, illustrated editions such as Collingwood's of Ruskin's poems, which was available in elegant “large” editions using special papers and bindings.

Thus, Ruskin's autobiographical project converges with cultural currents to produce the Poems (1891) as well as Allen's editions of Ruskin's early prose works, but Collingwood's edition also marks what cannot necessarily be said of Allen's editions—a significant step forward in scholarly treatment of Ruskin's work. It was no mean accomplishment that Collingwood built his edition on the first descriptive bibliography of Ruskin manuscripts, the “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” (Ruskin, Poems [8o, 1891], 1:261–67; Ruskin, Poems [4o, 1891], 1:???). This, too, reflected a trend, for bibliographical scholarship on modern authors' published works had been burgeoning in recent decades, in response to the collecting phenomenon and to the needs of the author societies forming around Britain. By 1890, Collingwood could rely on three bibliographical projects on Ruskin, which were underway throughout the 1870s–90s were:

list.item: Bibliography of Ruskin (5 editions, 1878–81) by Richard Herne Shepherd;
John Ruskin: A Bibliographical Biography (1879) by William E. A. Axon;
Complete Bibliography of . . . Ruskin (1893) by James P. Smart and Thomas J. Wise.

div.p: This scholarship cannot be separated from the phenomena previously noted as influencing Collingwood's project--autobiographical or biographical interests, and the desires of collectors. As compiled for collectors, the bibliographies tended to be concerned with establishing what constituted a perfect copy of a given item; and even that much description may have been established rather arbitrarily, based on copies the bibliographer happened to have available. This approach, as remarked by the “new bibliography” of the 1930s–40s, lacked historical awareness of “the changing processes, trade customs, methods of distribution and book‐buyersʼ tastes which made [these books] what they are,” (Sadleir, “Development of Bibliographical Study”, 147). A more historical approach would have required a self‐consciousness on the part of fin-de-siècle collectors themselves much less a perspective on Ruskin's own practices in bookmaking and distribution. Despite their limitations, the modern author bibliographies of the last quarter of the century were careful scholarly achievements.

These bibliographies also were not only influenced by, but also helped to sponsor an interest in modern authors' Childhood, Precocity, and Juvenilia. Bibliographers and collectors of the 1870s-80s were keen to unearth scarce publications by famous maodern authors, since such discoveries bolstered claims to comprehensiveness. This archaeology favored juvenile and youthful publications by virtue of their scarcity, such works having been published prior to the author's achieving fame.

As explained in Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries, an interest in juvenilia or other “minor” works was, in the view of post-war bibliographers, an unscholarly “sentiment” that grew out of the late-Victorian collecting phenomenon. Collectors, it was later argued, were prone to rearing nostalgic, imaginary scenarios involving their "first editions," a sentimentality that distracted from rigorous scholarship. This self-serving narrative overlooks evidence that a taste for famous authors' juvenilia worked also in the opposite direction—a sentiment for childhood sponsoring collectors' search for juvenilia. This tendency shows in the career of Richard Herne Shepherd, Ruskin's first major bibliographer, and this decades-old relation between sentiment for youth and the collecting market apparently buoyed prices for the early Ruskin manuscripts as well, when these became available at the Sotheby's Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1930 and the Sotheby's Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1931.

Thus, in the mix of metaphors opening the introduction to Poems (1891), it is not that Collingwood's appeal to “sympathy” for the subject is betrayed by a desire to “own” the subject, but that sympathy justified and sponsored possession: "It is no idle curiosity . . . that prompts the admirers of Mr. Ruskin's works to collect his boyish writings and to learn the story of his youth." Collingwood argued that Ruskin "more than other writers" required "a preliminary understanding of his ways, and aims, and attitude: and in his case, more than with others, these conditions have been determined at an early age, and illustrated in his early writings" (Ruskin, Poems [8o, 1891], 1:???; Ruskin, Poems [4o, 1891], 1:xix–xx). In fact, readers of the period appear to have been predisposed to approach writers in this fashion.

The new bibliographers' eagerness to condemn the “sentiment” and “greed” of collectors was colored by the revelation that the fever for collector's items had provided T. H. Wise his opening for exploitation, using the 1893 bibliography as a platform to stage descriptions of nonexistent Ruskinalia. These included Ruskin's alleged pamphlet-length reprintings of juvenile poems, which Wise manufactured and spirited into the market as scarce surviving copies. Using this ingenious scheme, Wise and Buxton Forman bedeviled the bibliography of numerous modern authors, but it was doubts raised in the Library Edition about the Ruskin pamphlets in particular that led to Carter and Pollard's exposé of wise. As explained in Forgery and Piracy, this clandestine industry was intricately involved in the climate of rare book and facsimile collecting in the fin de siècle, and not a linear outcome of collectors' sentimentality calling forth exploitation.

All these approaches to studying and collecting modern authors at fin de siècle shared a biographical orientation to their subjects. Collectors believed that, by acquiring a comprehensive material record of an author's productions, one gained insight into the author's career; and literary men like Richard Herne Shepherd encouraged this conviction respecting Tennyson or Barrett Browning no less than for Ruskin, Shepherd arguing in his Tennysoniana that study of "'the growth of a Poet's mind'" required acquaintance with the early Poems by Two Brothers (1827), just as he maintained in The Earlier Poems of Elizabeth Barrett Browning that time spent with An Essay on Mind (1826) served as "an exquisite day of April" dawning on the "fervid day in August" in Aurora Leigh (Shepherd, Tennysoniana, v; Barrett Browning, Earlier Poems, ed. Shepherd, viii). If Ruskin, as Collingwood argued, benefited "more than other authors" from an approach via his early work, this seemed true only because Ruskin himself had prompted the approach. Axon could start his Bibliographical Biography (1879) of Ruskin with a juvenile poem because Ruskin himself printed the poem in Queen of the Air. In drawing attention to his juvenilia, Ruskin was indeed unusual among Victorian authors; nonetheless, the bio-bibliographical impulse could prevail over the wishes even of authors who were hostile to publication of early efforts and first states of their work. No literary executor could have been more vigilant in this regard than Hallam Tennyson, the poet's son; yet, as Michael Millgate has remarked, Hallam apparently "recognized no contradiction between his deliberate preservation and publication of juvenilia and rejected readings and his insistence upon [his father's] desire to be represented only by his authorized final canon in its final form" (Millgate, Testamentary Acts, 61).

div.head: The Library Edition and the Rise of a Documentary Approach to the Early Manuscripts
div.p: So far as scholarship surrounding the early writing is concerned, the next stage, the editing of the Library Edition, can in some respects be seen as an extension of the culture and achievements of the 1890s. Owing in part to George Allen's rush to publish the first two volumes (1903) of the new edition and to show subscribers an earnest of the publisher's promises, these volumes represented more a reprise, even a reprint, of previous efforts, rather than a new editorial approach. Allen's editions of the early prose works and Collingwood's Poems (1891) respectively make up large parts of the volumes of Early Prose and Poems. Enough was done, however, to reflect the philosophy of the editors, E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn, that a collected edition should be comprehensive, without suppressing previously published works, as Ruskin had done in the Works Series. The editors also planned to show previous states of texts that Ruskin had revised and to print previously unpublished material, including manuscript versions of published works, and private materials such as letters, diaries, and notes. While far more revealing than what late Victorian collected editions typically authorized, the Library Edition blended its ostensibly historical and documentary approach to editing with an essentially aesthetic orientation. The editors generally presented the final state of a text (although in some cases, they created an eclectic text) and relegated previous states, draft or alternate published versions, to notes. Their choice of the latter witnesses seems arbitrary, governed by what appealed to them for reasons that they leave unstated.

Cook and Wedderburn did make some advances over Collingwood, however, and delivered on their promise of greater comprehensiveness by extending Collingwood's “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems” to include early prose manuscripts. As indicated by Cook and Wedderburn's manuscript descriptions enhancing “Notes on the Original MSS. of the Poems [Revised and Completed from the Edition of 1891],” they were laying the basis for a more documentary approach with considerable sorting, describing, and preserving manuscripts at Brantwood (see Overview of the Manuscripts and Provenance). They also challenged the previous editor's portrayal of the early manuscripts as pristine, free of revision by the author and of emendation by his parents; rather, the new editors pointed to "a good deal of revision between draft and fair copy" (Ruskin, Works, 2:529n)

and, further, how this production might be woven “into the lives of their authors, producing as it were a garment of biography with a texture of bibliography” . Still, Sadleir recognizes that the new taste for collecting moderns was informed by a significant level of bibliographic research.
